monogr.title: A true historie of the memorable siege of Ostend : and what passed on either side, from the beginning of the siege, vnto the yeelding vp of the towne. Conteining the assaults, alarums, defences, inuentions of warre, mines, counter-mines and retrenchments, combats of galleys, and sea-fights, with the portrait of the towne: and also what passed in the Ile of Cadsant, and at the siege of Sluice, after the comming of Count Maurice. div.head: A description of the Chariot or Pompees bridge, inuented to giue an assault to the Halfe-Moone of the Spaniards at Ostend, as it appears in the plot of the towne.

list.item: A. The Bridge being let downe.
B. The Mast against the which the Bridge was raised, being 150. foote high.
C. The vpper part of the Bridge, made of great Roapes and Cables of Musket proofe.
D. The neather part of the Bridge made likewise of Roapes of Musket proofe.
E. A Poste like vnto the beame of a Wagon, to draw the Bridge vp, and to let it downe.
F. Foure-score horses to draw this Chariot.
G. Wheeles eight foote broad, and 14. or 15. high, the which are exceeding strong, and did cost 300. Ducats a peece.
H. Heere Musketiers should be placed to shoote at them of the Towne, and to keepe them from cutting of the Roape.

div.p: The Arch-duke after he had done what he could to take Ostend, or to annoy the besieged, by the inuention of an Italian Ingeneur named Pompee, he caused a Chariot to be made, or a Bridge called Helwagen or Loywagen, or Pompees Chariot, by the inuentors name, to go vnto the assault at the Spanish Halfe-moone, the which was made and held by them of the towne: the Bridge is 100. paces long & 16. broad: on the which ten may march in front, it hath foure Wheeles euery one 8. foote broad, and 14. or 15. high: at the end of the Chariot there is a tree or mast 150. foote high, by meanes whereof the bridge is drawne vp and let downe with poollies. Their desseigne was to fasten Anchors on either side of the Halfe-moone, against the which 80. horses should draw the bridge, as it is set downe in the Figure. They of the Towne hauing intelligence thereof, made a high Palyssadoe with trauerses of masts like vnto Gibets, to receiue the vpper part of the bridge, being let downe: the besieged seeing this bridge approach neere vnto the Halfe-moone, they brake one of the Wheeles with a Canon-shot, so as it was of no effect, which made thē of the towne call it the Cowards-bridge.
